questions.text: M/C lymph node involved Ca Cervix :
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Obturator lymph node. In cervical cancer, the obturator lymph node is the most common lymph node group involved in the metastatic spread. These lymph nodes are located near the pelvis, particularly in the region surrounding the obturator foramen, and are often the first site of lymphatic spread in cervical cancer. The spread to these lymph nodes typically occurs as the cancer progresses from the cervix to the adjacent pelvic structures. The involvement of obturator lymph nodes is an important indicator of more advanced stages of cervical cancer and has prognostic significance. Explanation for the incorrect responses: B. Inguinal: The inguinal lymph nodes are generally not the first to be involved in cervical cancer. These nodes are located in the lower abdomen and groin area and are usually affected in advanced stages of cervical cancer. Inguinal lymph node involvement often occurs later in the disease when the cancer has spread significantly beyond the pelvic region. Thus, the inguinal nodes are not the most common site for early metastasis in cervical cancer. C. Internal iliac: The internal iliac lymph nodes are part of the pelvic lymph node group and can be involved in the spread of cervical cancer, but they are not the most common site of metastasis initially. These nodes drain the uterus and cervix but are typically affected in more advanced stages or when the cancer has already spread to other nearby pelvic nodes. D. External iliac: The external iliac lymph nodes are another group of pelvic nodes that can be involved in the metastasis of cervical cancer. While they are involved in the spread, they are usually not the first lymph nodes to be affected. The external iliac lymph nodes drain the lower abdomen and parts of the pelvis, and their involvement may be seen in advanced cervical cancer, but they are not the most common site of initial involvement.

questions.text: All are true with regards to pregnancy luteoma except
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) True tumor. A pregnancy luteoma is a benign condition that occurs during pregnancy and is characterized by the development of hormonally active masses in the ovaries. These masses are typically composed of luteinized cells that are overstimulated during pregnancy. Despite their size and hormonal activity, pregnancy luteomas are not considered true tumors because they do not have malignant potential. They are functional ovarian cysts that arise as a result of the hormonal changes during pregnancy and usually resolve after delivery without any long-term consequences. Explanation for the incorrect responses: A. Can lead to virilization: Pregnancy luteomas can produce high levels of androgens (male hormones), which can lead to virilization in the pregnant woman. This can cause symptoms such as increased body hair, a deepened voice, and other signs of masculinization. These symptoms occur due to the hormonal production by the luteoma, and while the virilization typically resolves after delivery, it is a common feature of the condition. C. Bilateral usually: Pregnancy luteomas are often bilateral, meaning they are found on both ovaries. This bilateral nature is a characteristic feature of pregnancy luteomas and helps differentiate them from other ovarian conditions. They typically occur in the second or third trimester of pregnancy and can sometimes be mistaken for ovarian tumors, but their bilateral presentation is a distinctive aspect of the condition. D. Regress spontaneously after delivery: Pregnancy luteomas typically regress spontaneously after delivery. Once the pregnancy ends and the hormonal environment changes, the luteomas generally shrink and resolve without the need for any medical intervention. This is a key characteristic of pregnancy luteomas, and their benign nature means that no surgical treatment is usually necessary unless there are complications.

questions.text: All of the following are germ cell tumors of the ovaryexcept:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Fibroma. A fibroma is not a germ cell tumor of the ovary. It is a stromal tumor that arises from the connective tissue of the ovary. Fibromas are benign tumors that are typically composed of fibrous tissue and are usually asymptomatic, although large fibromas can cause symptoms due to their size or pressure on surrounding structures. These tumors are different from germ cell tumors, which originate from the reproductive cells (the germ cells) of the ovary. Explanation for the incorrect responses: A. Teratoma: A teratoma is a germ cell tumor and is one of the most common types of ovarian tumors. It is composed of tissue from all three germ layers (ectoderm, mesoderm, and endoderm), and it often contains a variety of different tissues, such as hair, teeth, and fatty tissue. Teratomas can be either mature (benign) or immature (potentially malignant), and they are considered germ cell tumors because they arise from the reproductive cells of the ovary. C. Dysgerminoma: A dysgerminoma is a germ cell tumor and is the most common malignant germ cell tumor of the ovary, particularly in young women. It is similar to a seminoma in men and is often treated successfully with surgery and chemotherapy. Dysgerminomas are typically unilateral and are composed of undifferentiated germ cells. They are considered one of the classic types of ovarian germ cell tumors. D. Endodermal sinus tumor: An endodermal sinus tumor (also known as a yolk sac tumor) is another germ cell tumor that arises from the yolk sac cells. This tumor is typically aggressive and can occur in both the ovaries and testes. It often produces elevated levels of alpha-fetoprotein (AFP) and is considered a malignant germ cell tumor of the ovary. Like dysgerminomas, endodermal sinus tumors are treated with a combination of surgery and chemotherapy.

choices.text: Sertoli-Leydig cell tumors of the ovary

questions.text: Sex cord stromal tumors of the ovary include all except:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Luteomas. Luteomas are not sex cord-stromal tumors of the ovary. They are hormone-producing tumors that can develop during pregnancy, typically seen in the ovaries. These tumors are composed of luteinized cells and are usually benign. Luteomas can lead to virilization in pregnant women because they produce androgens, but they are not classified as sex cord-stromal tumors, which arise from the ovarian stroma or sex cord cells. Explanation for the incorrect responses: B. Gynandroblastomas: Gynandroblastomas are indeed sex cord-stromal tumors. These tumors are a rare type of ovarian tumor that contains both male and female sex cord elements, typically with the presence of Sertoli and granulosa cells. These tumors are mixed-gender in origin and are classified as sex cord-stromal tumors because they arise from the sex cord of the ovary. C. Sertoli-Leydig cell tumors of the ovary: Sertoli-Leydig cell tumors are another type of sex cord-stromal tumor. These tumors consist of Sertoli cells (which support sperm development in the testes) and Leydig cells (which produce testosterone in both men and women). Sertoli-Leydig cell tumors can cause virilization due to the production of testosterone and are classified as sex cord-stromal tumors because they arise from the cells of the ovary's stroma or sex cord.

questions.text: M/C functional cyst of ovary is
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Follicular cyst. Follicular cysts are the most common functional cysts of the ovary. They develop when a follicle fails to rupture and release an egg during the normal ovulation process. This causes the follicle to continue growing, forming a cyst. Follicular cysts are typically benign and often resolve on their own without the need for intervention. They are considered functional because they arise as part of the normal ovarian cycle. Explanation for the incorrect responses: A. Chocolate cyst: A chocolate cyst (also known as an endometrioma) is a type of ovarian cyst that occurs when endometrial tissue grows on the ovaries, a condition commonly associated with endometriosis. These cysts are filled with old blood, which gives them the "chocolate" appearance on ultrasound. Chocolate cysts are not functional cysts; they are pathological and related to endometriosis. C. Dermoid cyst: A dermoid cyst is a type of benign ovarian tumor that originates from germ cells. These cysts can contain various tissues such as hair, skin, and teeth. While dermoid cysts are common ovarian tumors, they are not considered functional cysts because they arise from germ cell tissue rather than the normal follicular or luteal changes in the ovarian cycle. D. Corpus luteal cyst: A corpus luteal cyst forms after ovulation, when the corpus luteum (the structure left behind after the egg is released) does not regress as it normally should. Instead, it fills with fluid, creating a cyst. Although corpus luteal cysts are functional cysts, they are less common than follicular cysts. Additionally, they are associated with pregnancy, as they produce progesterone to support early pregnancy until the placenta takes over hormone production.

questions.text: Lutein cysts are associated with all except:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Use of OCP's. Lutein cysts are primarily associated with conditions that alter hormonal balances, such as gestational trophoblastic diseases, clomiphene administration, and bilaterality. However, the use of oral contraceptives (OCPs) does not typically result in lutein cyst formation. In fact, OCPs are designed to suppress ovulation and prevent the formation of functional ovarian cysts, including lutein cysts. Explanation for the incorrect responses: A. Gestational trophoblastic tumors: Gestational trophoblastic disease (GTD), including conditions like molar pregnancy, is strongly associated with the formation of lutein cysts. These tumors produce elevated levels of human chorionic gonadotropin (hCG), which stimulates the ovaries and leads to the development of lutein cysts. Bilateral lutein cysts are often seen in GTD. B. Clomiphene administration: Clomiphene citrate is a medication used to induce ovulation, particularly in women with anovulatory infertility. It can lead to the development of lutein cysts as a result of overstimulation of the ovaries, causing excessive follicular development. This is a well-known side effect of clomiphene use. C. Bilaterality: Bilaterality is a characteristic feature of lutein cysts, especially in conditions like gestational trophoblastic disease or Clomiphene administration. In these cases, the ovaries are typically overstimulated, leading to the development of cysts on both sides.

questions.text: A 52-years-old postmenopausal female presents unilocular with a ovarian cyst of 6 cm with normal Ca125levels management is
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Wait and watch. In a 52-year-old postmenopausal woman with a unilocular ovarian cyst of 6 cm and normal CA-125 levels, the management is typically watchful waiting. A simple ovarian cyst (unilocular, benign in appearance) in a postmenopausal woman that is asymptomatic, and with normal CA-125 levels, generally does not warrant immediate surgical intervention. Most of these cysts are benign and may resolve spontaneously or remain stable over time. Routine follow-up imaging after 6-12 weeks is recommended to monitor for any changes in size or characteristics. Explanation for the incorrect responses: A. USG guided ovarian tapping: Ultrasound-guided ovarian tapping (aspiration of the cyst fluid) is not the first-line approach for managing a simple ovarian cyst, especially in postmenopausal women with no concerning features (such as abnormal CA-125 levels, or irregular cyst characteristics). Tapping is typically used for functional cysts or when there is concern about a larger cyst causing pressure or discomfort. In this case, the cyst is simple and small (6 cm), and the risk of malignancy is low, so aspiration is unnecessary. C. Surgery: Surgery is generally reserved for complex cysts, suspicious masses, or cysts that cause symptoms. Given the benign characteristics of the cyst in this case, surgery is not indicated unless there is growth or changes in the cyst over time, or if the patient becomes symptomatic. Surgical intervention would be considered if follow-up imaging shows significant changes or if the patient develops symptoms such as pain or bloating. D. OCP: Oral contraceptive pills (OCPs) are not routinely used for the management of simple ovarian cysts, particularly in postmenopausal women. OCPs are more commonly used for functional cysts in younger women to suppress ovulation, but in postmenopausal women, ovarian cysts are not typically linked to ovulation, so OCPs would not be beneficial. Furthermore, the goal for postmenopausal women is often observation rather than hormonal therapy.

questions.text: M/C benign ovarian tumor is:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Serous cystadenoma. Serous cystadenomas are the most common type of benign ovarian tumors. These tumors are typically unilocular or multilocular cystic lesions that are lined by serous epithelium and contain a clear, watery fluid. They are typically benign and account for a significant proportion of ovarian neoplasms, especially in women in their 30s and 40s. They are most often found incidentally during imaging for other reasons and usually have a good prognosis. Explanation for the incorrect responses: B. Mucinous cystadenoma: Mucinous cystadenomas are the second most common benign ovarian tumor. These tumors are characterized by their thick mucinous fluid and can become quite large. Although they are common, they are less frequent than serous cystadenomas. Mucinous cystadenomas tend to have a more complex appearance and may involve more than one cyst, but they are still considered benign in most cases. However, they can present with complications like torsion or rupture. C. Mature cystic teratoma: Mature cystic teratomas, also known as dermoid cysts, are another common benign ovarian tumor, but they are less frequent than serous cystadenomas. They contain tissue from all three germ layers (ectoderm, mesoderm, and endoderm), such as hair, sebaceous glands, or teeth. While they are benign, they can cause complications like torsion, infection, or rupture, which makes them important to manage appropriately. However, they are not as common as serous cystadenomas. D. Immature cystic teratoma: Immature cystic teratomas are rare and are typically malignant ovarian tumors, especially in younger women. They are composed of immature tissue and are often associated with more aggressive behavior. While teratomas can be benign (mature cystic teratomas), immature teratomas are a different entity and are much less common. The malignancy potential of immature teratomas distinguishes them from the more common benign forms.

questions.text: Psammoma bodies are see in:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Serous tumors. Serous tumors, particularly serous cystadenomas and serous cystadenocarcinomas, are the most commonly associated with psammoma bodies. Psammoma bodies are calcified, round, lamellated structures often seen in certain ovarian tumors, especially serous tumors. They are believed to form as a result of necrosis and calcification within the tumor. The presence of psammoma bodies is considered a characteristic feature in the histopathology of these tumors and is often used to help diagnose serous cystadenocarcinomas. Explanation for the incorrect responses: B. Brenner tumor: Brenner tumors are benign ovarian neoplasms composed of transitional cell epithelium. While they may have a characteristic honeycomb pattern on histology, they are not typically associated with psammoma bodies. Although psammoma bodies can sometimes be seen in other tumors, they are not characteristic of Brenner tumors, which is why this answer is incorrect. C. Fibroma: Fibromas are benign ovarian tumors made up of fibrous tissue. They do not typically contain psammoma bodies. While they can present with certain clinical features such as ascites (Meigs syndrome) and pleural effusion, they are not associated with psammoma bodies, which are seen more commonly in serous tumors. Therefore, this option is incorrect. D. Endodermal sinus tumor: Endodermal sinus tumors, also known as yolk sac tumors, are germ cell tumors of the ovary. They are characterized by the presence of Schiller-Duval bodies but do not typically contain psammoma bodies. While endodermal sinus tumors are aggressive and often present with high AFP levels, psammoma bodies are not a feature of this tumor type, making this answer incorrect.

questions.text: Dash and dot appearance on USG is seen in:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Dermoid cyst of ovary. Dermoid cysts of the ovary are characterized by a "dash and dot" appearance on ultrasound. This appearance is due to the presence of calcifications and sebum within the cyst, which give a multilayered echogenic pattern. The dots represent the solid components, such as hair, teeth, or sebaceous material, while the dashes reflect the fluid-filled areas within the cyst. This unique sonographic feature is highly suggestive of a mature cystic teratoma, also known as a dermoid cyst, and helps distinguish it from other types of ovarian cysts. Explanation for the incorrect responses: A. Adenomyosis: Adenomyosis, a condition where endometrial tissue grows into the myometrium (muscle layer of the uterus), typically presents with a bulky, globular uterus and heterogeneous myometrial echotexture on ultrasound. It does not show a dash and dot appearance. Instead, ultrasound findings may include myometrial cysts or a "swiss cheese" pattern. Therefore, this option is incorrect. C. Molar pregnancy: Molar pregnancies, which are abnormal pregnancies characterized by the growth of cystic, grape-like clusters of trophoblastic tissue, are usually seen on ultrasound as a mass of fluid-filled sacs or a "snowstorm" pattern. This is very different from the dash and dot appearance of a dermoid cyst. Molar pregnancies do not display the same characteristic echogenic features seen in dermoid cysts. Thus, this answer is incorrect. D. Serous tumors of ovary: Serous tumors, including serous cystadenomas and serous cystadenocarcinomas, often present as smooth, thin-walled cystic masses on ultrasound, with unilocular or multilocular cysts. These tumors do not have the dash and dot appearance associated with dermoid cysts. Instead, they may exhibit septations or solid components within the cyst. Therefore, this is not the correct answer.

questions.text: Percentage chances of ovarian cancer, in first degreerelatives, if a 65 years old female dies to ovarian cancerwithin first year of its detection:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) No risk. In general, ovarian cancer risk in first-degree relatives (i.e., mother, sister, or daughter) is higher compared to the general population. However, the risk does not increase in a straightforward manner based on the age of the relative who develops ovarian cancer, or how quickly the cancer progresses (such as within the first year of diagnosis). The key point here is that the risk is related to genetic predisposition, and it is not significantly altered by the specific timing of the cancer diagnosis or the age of the individual at the time of death, unless there is an underlying hereditary syndrome, like BRCA1/2 mutations. For women without such genetic mutations, the overall risk of ovarian cancer remains relatively low, and a death within the first year of diagnosis does not substantially increase the risk for her first-degree relatives. Hence, the risk is no higher based solely on the timing of death after diagnosis. Explanation for the incorrect responses: A. 3%: The risk for ovarian cancer in first-degree relatives of women with ovarian cancer who do not carry specific genetic mutations (like BRCA1/2) is generally lower than 3%. While family history is a risk factor, a percentage as high as 3% would typically be seen in cases where there are strong genetic links or hereditary conditions. This answer is therefore incorrect. B. 10%: A 10% risk would be seen in the case of strong hereditary links, such as BRCA mutations or Lynch syndrome, which are associated with a significantly higher risk for ovarian cancer. However, in the absence of such mutations, the risk for first-degree relatives of women who die from ovarian cancer is not generally this high, making this option incorrect. C. 15%: A 15% risk would suggest a very high hereditary predisposition to ovarian cancer, often linked with well-documented genetic mutations such as BRCA1/2. Without a genetic mutation, the risk for first-degree relatives does not approach 15%. Therefore, this option is also incorrect for the context provided.

questions.text: M/C gene mutation in epithelial cell ovarian tumors:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) p53 gene. The most common genetic mutation in epithelial ovarian tumors is the p53 gene mutation. The p53 gene is a tumor suppressor gene, and mutations in this gene are frequently found in high-grade serous carcinoma, which is the most common type of ovarian cancer. p53 mutations are associated with the development of ovarian cancer and contribute to tumor progression by allowing the accumulation of additional genetic mutations, leading to uncontrolled cell division and survival. p53 mutations are considered a key driver in the development of epithelial ovarian carcinomas, particularly high-grade serous tumors. Explanation for the incorrect responses: B. KRAS: KRAS mutations are commonly associated with mucinous ovarian tumors and colorectal cancers, but they are not as commonly implicated in epithelial ovarian cancers overall, particularly the serous type. While KRAS mutations can play a role in some ovarian cancers, they are not the most common mutation, making this answer incorrect in the context of epithelial ovarian tumors as a whole. C. BRCA: While mutations in the BRCA1 and BRCA2 genes are associated with an increased risk of ovarian cancer, they are typically linked to a hereditary form of ovarian cancer, and their presence is not the most common mutation found in sporadic epithelial ovarian tumors. Women with BRCA mutations have a significantly higher lifetime risk of developing ovarian cancer, but p53 mutations are still more prevalent in the general population of epithelial ovarian cancer cases, especially sporadic cases, making this option less appropriate than p53 mutations. D. PTEN: PTEN is a tumor suppressor gene implicated in several types of cancer, including endometrial cancer and breast cancer, as well as in certain syndromes like Cowden syndrome. However, PTEN mutations are not as commonly found in epithelial ovarian tumors compared to p53 mutations. Therefore, this option is incorrect in the context of the most common gene mutations in ovarian cancer.

questions.text: M/C ovarian cancer associated with endometriosis:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Clear cell tumor. Explanation for the Correct Response: Clear cell tumors of the ovary are the most common type of ovarian cancer associated with endometriosis. Clear cell carcinoma is a subtype of epithelial ovarian cancer that is often linked to endometriosis, particularly when endometriotic lesions undergo malignant transformation. These tumors are characterized by their unique histological features, including clear cytoplasm, and are often found in women with a history of pelvic endometriosis. Clear cell tumors associated with endometriosis tend to be resistant to standard chemotherapy and can be aggressive, which makes early detection and management critical. Explanation for the Incorrect Responses: A. Endometrioid tumor: While endometrioid tumors are also associated with endometriosis, they are less commonly linked compared to clear cell tumors. Endometrioid ovarian carcinoma can arise in the setting of endometriosis, but clear cell carcinoma remains the most frequent type associated with this condition. Hence, this option is incorrect. C. Germ cell tumor: Germ cell tumors of the ovary originate from the germ cells (cells that produce eggs) and are not typically associated with endometriosis. These tumors are more commonly seen in younger women and include types like dysgerminomas and teratomas, which are unrelated to endometriosis. This makes this option incorrect. D. Brenner tumor: Brenner tumors are rare ovarian tumors that are part of the epithelial tumor group, but they are not associated with endometriosis. Brenner tumors are usually benign and arise independently of endometriotic lesions, making this the incorrect choice.

questions.text: Para-aortic lymph node involvement is seen in whichstage of ovarian cancer :
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Stage IIIA. Explanation for the Correct Response: In Stage IIIA ovarian cancer, there is microscopic peritoneal metastasis beyond the pelvis, including involvement of the retroperitoneal lymph nodes such as the para-aortic lymph nodes. This stage indicates that the cancer has spread from the ovaries to the abdominal cavity and/or retroperitoneal lymph nodes, but macroscopic peritoneal metastasis is not yet visible. The classification of ovarian cancer stages follows the FIGO (International Federation of Gynecology and Obstetrics) staging system, and para-aortic lymph node involvement is an important characteristic of Stage III disease. Explanation for the Incorrect Responses: A. Stage IIA: Stage IIA ovarian cancer involves extension or metastasis to the uterus and/or fallopian tubes, but it does not include retroperitoneal lymph node involvement such as the para-aortic nodes. At this stage, the disease is limited to the pelvis. Hence, this option is incorrect. B. Stage IIB: In Stage IIB, ovarian cancer has extended to other pelvic tissues (e.g., bladder or rectum), but it still does not involve retroperitoneal lymph nodes or peritoneal metastasis beyond the pelvis. Para-aortic lymph node involvement does not occur in this stage, making this option incorrect. D. Stage IIIB: Stage IIIB involves visible peritoneal metastasis beyond the pelvis that measures ?2 cm in diameter, with or without retroperitoneal lymph node involvement. While para-aortic lymph node involvement may occur, it is more characteristic of Stage IIIA, which specifically denotes microscopic metastasis and retroperitoneal lymph node involvement before visible abdominal spread. Thus, this option is less accurate than Stage IIIA.

questions.text: Germ cell tumor with the best prognosis:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) A. Dysgerminoma Dysgerminoma is the germ cell tumor with the best prognosis due to its high sensitivity to chemotherapy and radiotherapy, even in advanced stages. These tumors are usually diagnosed in younger women and are often unilateral, allowing fertility-preserving treatment. Dysgerminomas have a high cure rate, exceeding 90%, when detected early, and even advanced cases respond well to treatment, making this the germ cell tumor with the best overall prognosis. Explanation for the Incorrect Answers: B. Teratoma While mature teratomas (dermoid cysts) are benign and have an excellent prognosis, the question refers to germ cell tumors as a category, which includes immature teratomas. Immature teratomas are malignant, and their prognosis depends on the grade of immaturity. Lower-grade immature teratomas have a favorable outcome, but they do not surpass dysgerminomas in terms of prognosis, especially for higher-grade cases. C. Endodermal sinus tumor Endodermal sinus tumors (yolk sac tumors) are highly malignant and aggressive germ cell tumors. They grow rapidly and are associated with a worse prognosis compared to dysgerminomas. Although they respond to chemotherapy, the prognosis remains poorer than dysgerminomas due to the aggressive nature of these tumors. D. Embryonal carcinoma Embryonal carcinomas are rare and highly aggressive germ cell tumors. They are less responsive to treatment and tend to spread early, which results in a worse prognosis compared to dysgerminomas. While modern chemotherapeutic regimens have improved outcomes, embryonal carcinoma still does not match the prognosis of dysgerminomas.

questions.text: Ovarian tumor seen in dysgenetic gonads:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) D. Dysgerminoma Dysgerminoma is the most common ovarian tumor associated with dysgenetic gonads, such as in cases of gonadal dysgenesis or Turner syndrome (45,X/46,XY mosaicism). Dysgenetic gonads are at a high risk of developing malignant tumors, and dysgerminoma, a type of germ cell tumor, is the most frequent malignancy observed in such cases. It is highly sensitive to chemotherapy and radiotherapy, making it treatable with a good prognosis when detected early. Dysgerminomas are usually bilateral and occur in younger patients. Explanation for the Incorrect Answers: A. Serous cystadenocarcinoma Serous cystadenocarcinoma is an epithelial ovarian tumor, not typically associated with dysgenetic gonads. These tumors occur more frequently in older, postmenopausal women and arise from the surface epithelium of the ovary, making this an incorrect option in the context of dysgenetic gonads. B. Endodermal sinus tumor Endodermal sinus tumor (yolk sac tumor) is a germ cell tumor, but it is less commonly associated with dysgenetic gonads. These tumors are aggressive, occur more frequently in children and young adults, and are not specifically linked to gonadal dysgenesis as dysgerminomas are. C. Granulosa cell tumor Granulosa cell tumors are sex cord-stromal tumors and are not related to dysgenetic gonads. These tumors are hormone-producing and are typically seen in patients with normal gonadal development. Their occurrence in the context of dysgenetic gonads is rare.

choices.text: The most common primary site is pylorus of the stomach

questions.text: The following statements are related to Krukenbergtumor except:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) A. It is always secondary This statement is incorrect because although Krukenberg tumors are almost always secondary, there are extremely rare instances where primary ovarian tumors can histologically resemble Krukenberg tumors. The hallmark of a Krukenberg tumor is that it is most often a metastatic ovarian tumor originating from a primary site, most commonly the gastrointestinal tract (especially the stomach). However, to state it is "always" secondary is inaccurate. Explanation for the Incorrect Answers: B. The most common primary site is the pylorus of the stomach This is a correct statement. The majority of Krukenberg tumors metastasize from adenocarcinomas of the stomach, specifically from the pylorus region. Other common sites include the colon, appendix, and breast, but the stomach remains the most frequent origin. C. The tumor is bilateral This is correct. Krukenberg tumors are characteristically bilateral in most cases, which is a distinguishing feature when compared to many primary ovarian tumors. This bilateral involvement reflects their metastatic nature. D. 'Signet ring' looking cells are characteristic This is correct. The presence of "signet ring" cells, which are mucin-filled cells with nuclei displaced to one side, is a hallmark microscopic feature of Krukenberg tumors. These cells confirm the metastatic origin of the tumor, often from a mucin-producing adenocarcinoma, such as that of the stomach.

questions.text: All of the following are known risk factors for the development of ovarian carcinoma except:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Use of oral pills The use of oral contraceptive pills (OCPs) is actually a protective factor against ovarian carcinoma, not a risk factor. Studies have consistently shown that long-term use of OCPs reduces the risk of developing ovarian cancer. The protective effect is thought to arise from suppression of ovulation, which reduces the number of times the ovarian epithelium is disrupted, thereby lowering the risk of malignant transformation. Explanation for the Incorrect Answers: A. Family history of ovarian carcinoma This is a known risk factor for ovarian cancer. Women with a first-degree relative (mother, sister, or daughter) who has had ovarian cancer have an increased risk of developing the disease. The familial clustering is often related to inherited genetic mutations such as BRCA1 or BRCA2. C. Use of Clomiphene Clomiphene, a drug used to induce ovulation in women with infertility, has been associated with an increased risk of ovarian cancer, particularly in women who have undergone multiple cycles of treatment without achieving pregnancy. This is thought to be related to the increased frequency of ovulation, which may lead to greater susceptibility to DNA damage in ovarian epithelial cells. D. BRCA-1 positive individual Individuals who carry a BRCA1 mutation have a significantly increased lifetime risk of developing ovarian cancer. BRCA2 mutations also elevate the risk, though to a slightly lesser degree. These genetic mutations impair the bodyâ€™s ability to repair DNA damage, leading to increased susceptibility to cancers.

questions.text: Which of the following strategy has been recommended to reduce the heredity risk for ovarian cancer in women with BRCA -1 and BRCA - 2 mutations?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Prophylactic oophorectomy Prophylactic bilateral salpingo-oophorectomy (removal of both ovaries and fallopian tubes) is the most effective strategy to significantly reduce the hereditary risk of ovarian cancer in women with BRCA1 and BRCA2 mutations. This preventive surgery reduces the risk of ovarian cancer by approximately 80â€“90% and also lowers the risk of breast cancer in premenopausal women. Since ovarian cancer is often diagnosed at an advanced stage and has no effective early detection methods, prophylactic surgery is strongly recommended for BRCA mutation carriers, typically after childbearing is complete or by age 35â€“40 for BRCA1 carriers and slightly later for BRCA2 carriers. Explanation for the Incorrect Answers: A. Use of oral contraceptive pills While the use of oral contraceptive pills (OCPs) has been shown to reduce the risk of ovarian cancer in the general population and even in BRCA mutation carriers, the risk reduction is not as substantial as that achieved by prophylactic oophorectomy. OCPs provide a protective effect by reducing the number of ovulatory cycles, but they do not eliminate the hereditary risk. B. Screening with transvaginal ultrasound Screening with transvaginal ultrasound (TVUS) is not recommended as an effective strategy for reducing hereditary ovarian cancer risk. TVUS has limited sensitivity and specificity for detecting early-stage ovarian cancer, especially in BRCA mutation carriers, and often leads to false positives and unnecessary interventions. C. Screening with CA-125 Screening with CA-125, a tumor marker, is also not effective as a standalone strategy to reduce hereditary ovarian cancer risk. CA-125 levels can be elevated due to other benign conditions, and it lacks the sensitivity and specificity to reliably detect early-stage ovarian cancer. Studies have shown that combining CA-125 with TVUS does not significantly improve survival rates for high-risk women.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most radiosensitive ovarian tumors?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) A. Dysgerminoma Dysgerminoma is the most radiosensitive ovarian tumor. This germ cell tumor is highly sensitive to radiation therapy, which makes it unique among ovarian tumors. Dysgerminomas are typically found in younger women and are often diagnosed at an early stage. Due to their radiosensitivity, radiation therapy can be a valuable treatment option for patients who cannot undergo surgery or require additional therapy. However, chemotherapy is now more commonly used due to its effectiveness and reduced long-term complications compared to radiation. Explanation for the Incorrect Answers: B. Dermoid cyst Dermoid cysts (mature cystic teratomas) are benign germ cell tumors and are not treated with radiation therapy. They are primarily managed through surgical removal. Dermoid cysts are not radiosensitive, as their components often include mature tissues such as skin, hair, and fat. C. Serous cystadenoma Serous cystadenomas are benign epithelial ovarian tumors and do not respond to radiation therapy. These tumors are managed surgically, and radiation has no role in their treatment. Radiosensitivity is not a characteristic of benign epithelial ovarian tumors. D. Endodermal sinus tumor Endodermal sinus tumors, also known as yolk sac tumors, are malignant germ cell tumors. They are not highly radiosensitive and are instead treated effectively with chemotherapy, particularly with regimens like BEP (bleomycin, etoposide, and cisplatin). Radiation is not a primary treatment modality for these tumors.

questions.text: Which of the following is correct regarding granulosa cell tumor of ovary?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) B. Associated with Ca endometrium Granulosa cell tumors of the ovary are sex cord-stromal tumors that are often hormonally active, producing excess estrogen. This hyperestrogenism can stimulate the endometrium, leading to endometrial hyperplasia, atypia, or even endometrial carcinoma (Ca endometrium). Approximately 5-10% of women with granulosa cell tumors develop concurrent or subsequent endometrial carcinoma. As such, endometrial sampling or biopsy is a critical step in the management of these patients to assess for associated endometrial pathology. Explanation for the Incorrect Answers: A. Common in puberty Granulosa cell tumors can occur at any age but are most common in peri- and postmenopausal women. While a rare subset known as juvenile granulosa cell tumors occurs in children and adolescents, the majority of granulosa cell tumors (adult type) are not common in puberty. Thus, this statement is misleading as a generalization. C. Malignant change occurs rarely Granulosa cell tumors are classified as low-grade malignant tumors, meaning they have malignant potential and a tendency to recur or metastasize over time. While they are generally slow-growing, the risk of recurrence can be significant, especially in advanced stages. Hence, this statement downplays their malignant behavior. D. It is bilateral Granulosa cell tumors are typically unilateral, meaning they occur in only one ovary. Bilateral presentation is very rare, unlike epithelial ovarian tumors such as serous carcinoma, which more commonly present bilaterally.

questions.text: Smt. Pushpa is a suspected case of ovarian tumors. On laparotomy bilaterally enlarged ovaries with smooth surface was seen:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) B. Krukenberg tumor A Krukenberg tumor refers to metastatic ovarian cancer, most commonly arising from gastric carcinoma, specifically from the signet ring cell variant of adenocarcinoma. These tumors are often bilateral and present with enlarged ovaries that have a smooth surface. The characteristic signet ring cells can be seen on histopathological examination. Krukenberg tumors are associated with other signs of metastasis and tend to involve both ovaries. Hence, this clinical presentation matches with the description of bilateral, enlarged ovaries with a smooth surface. Explanation for the Incorrect Answers: A. Granulosa cell tumor Granulosa cell tumors are usually unilateral, and although they can cause bilateral enlargement of the ovaries in some cases, they typically present with more distinct characteristics, such as estrogenic activity, and may not appear as smooth-surfaced tumors. The ovaries may be enlarged but the smooth surface is not a hallmark of granulosa cell tumors. C. Dysgerminoma Dysgerminomas are germ cell tumors and tend to present in younger women, often as unilateral masses. These tumors typically present as solid, smooth masses, but they are not commonly bilateral. The histology shows characteristic "fried egg" cells, but they do not typically present with smooth-surfaced, enlarged ovaries as described in this case. D. Primary adenocarcinoma Primary adenocarcinoma of the ovary typically presents with an irregular, nodular surface, not a smooth one. The tumor may also be unilateral in most cases, though it can be bilateral. However, primary adenocarcinomas usually present with more significant clinical findings such as ascites or other localizations of metastatic disease, and they would not typically be described as smooth-surfaced tumors.

questions.text: Pain of ovarian carcinoma is referred to:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) D. Medial surface of thigh Ovarian carcinoma often causes pain that is referred to the medial surface of the thigh due to the anatomical location of the ovarian nerves. The ovarian nerves derive from the lumbar and sacral plexuses, which can transmit pain sensations to the medial thigh area. This referred pain is a common manifestation in patients with advanced ovarian cancer due to the involvement of the pelvic structures and nearby nerves. Explanation for the Incorrect Answers: A. Back of thigh Referred pain to the back of the thigh is not typically associated with ovarian carcinoma. While pelvic and lower abdominal pain can radiate to different areas, the back of the thigh is more often related to conditions such as sciatica or other nerve compressions from the lower spine. B. Cervical region Pain referred to the cervical region is not common in ovarian carcinoma. The cervical region would typically be affected by conditions related to the cervix or upper reproductive tract, and not from ovarian cancer, which tends to cause lower abdominal or pelvic pain. C. Anterior surface of thigh While the anterior surface of the thigh may be involved in certain types of pelvic pain, it is not a typical site for referred pain from ovarian carcinoma. The anterior thigh pain is more commonly seen in conditions affecting the hip or femoral nerve but not in ovarian cancer.

questions.text: All are components of Meig's syndrome, except:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) D. Pericardial effusion Meig's syndrome is characterized by a triad of symptoms: ovarian tumor, ascites, and pleural effusion. Pericardial effusion is not a component of Meig's syndrome, and its presence would suggest a different pathology, such as cardiac or systemic conditions. The classic features of Meig's syndrome do not include pericardial involvement. Explanation for the Incorrect Answers: A. Pleural effusion Pleural effusion is one of the hallmark features of Meig's syndrome. It is typically a right-sided effusion and is caused by the mechanical pressure exerted by the ovarian tumor on the diaphragm, which in turn leads to fluid accumulation in the pleural cavity. This is one of the defining components of Meig's syndrome. B. Ovarian tumor An ovarian tumor, typically a benign fibroma, is a key component of Meig's syndrome. This benign tumor is usually unilateral and may be associated with ascites and pleural effusion. The tumor is often responsible for the other manifestations of the syndrome. C. Ascites Ascites is another common feature of Meig's syndrome. It is thought to be caused by the mechanical effects of the ovarian tumor or by increased vascular permeability due to the tumor. Ascites often resolves after the removal of the ovarian tumor, which is characteristic of the syndrome.

questions.text: The pseudomyxoma peritonei occurs as a complication of the following ovarian tumors:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) B. Mucinous cystadenoma Pseudomyxoma peritonei is most commonly associated with mucinous cystadenomas of the ovary. This condition occurs when there is rupture or spillage of the mucinous contents from the ovarian tumor into the peritoneal cavity. The mucinous material then leads to the accumulation of a gelatinous substance, causing the characteristic appearance of pseudomyxoma peritonei. Mucinous cystadenomas are benign tumors, but if they rupture, they can lead to this serious complication. Explanation for the Incorrect Answers: A. Serous cystadenoma Serous cystadenomas are another type of benign ovarian tumor, but they are not typically associated with pseudomyxoma peritonei. These tumors tend to have a watery or serous fluid inside, rather than the mucinous material that is characteristic of pseudomyxoma peritonei. Therefore, serous cystadenomas do not cause this complication. C. Dysgerminoma Dysgerminomas are germ cell tumors and are not associated with pseudomyxoma peritonei. They are malignant tumors and present differently from mucinous cystadenomas. Dysgerminomas typically do not produce the mucinous substance that leads to pseudomyxoma peritonei. D. Gonadoblastoma Gonadoblastomas are rare tumors that arise from the gonadal tissue, usually in individuals with abnormal sex chromosomes (e.g., Turner syndrome). These tumors do not typically lead to pseudomyxoma peritonei. Like dysgerminomas, they present with different pathologies compared to mucinous cystadenomas.

questions.text: Attacks of flushing and cyanosis occur in which type of ovarian tumors:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) D. Carcinoid tumors of ovary Carcinoid tumors of the ovary are a type of neuroendocrine tumor that often produce serotonin and other bioactive substances. This can lead to carcinoid syndrome, which is characterized by flushing and cyanosis. The serotonin released by these tumors causes increased blood flow to the skin, resulting in flushing. In some cases, serotonin can also lead to a constriction of blood vessels, which contributes to the cyanosis. These symptoms are more likely to occur when the tumor metastasizes to the liver, where it can release its products into the systemic circulation. Explanation for the Incorrect Answers: A. Struma ovarii Struma ovarii is an ovarian tumor composed primarily of thyroid tissue. While it may lead to hyperthyroid symptoms due to increased thyroid hormone production, it is not typically associated with flushing or cyanosis. The symptoms of struma ovarii are more related to thyroid dysfunction, such as weight loss, heat intolerance, and palpitations, rather than flushing and cyanosis. B. Krukenberg's tumor Krukenberg's tumor refers to metastatic ovarian cancer, often originating from gastrointestinal sites like the stomach. While Krukenberg tumors can cause abdominal symptoms and other signs related to the metastatic disease, they do not typically result in flushing or cyanosis. The main concern with Krukenberg's tumors is their association with gastrointestinal malignancies, not with systemic symptoms like flushing or cyanosis. C. Arrhenoblastoma Arrhenoblastomas are ovarian tumors that produce male hormones (androgens), which can lead to virilization in affected women. This includes symptoms like deepening of the voice, hirsutism, and clitoromegaly. These tumors do not cause flushing or cyanosis, as their effects are more related to hormonal imbalances, particularly the overproduction of androgens. E. Granulosa cell tumor Granulosa cell tumors are ovarian tumors that produce estrogen. Symptoms typically include abnormal uterine bleeding and signs of estrogen excess, such as breast tenderness or endometrial hyperplasia. However, granulosa cell tumors are not associated with flushing or cyanosis. Their symptoms are primarily linked to estrogen activity rather than the serotonin release seen in carcinoid tumors.

questions.text: Most common ovarian cyst to undergo torsion:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) A. Benign cystic teratoma Benign cystic teratomas, also known as dermoid cysts, are the most common ovarian cysts to undergo torsion. These cysts contain various tissues such as hair, skin, and teeth. Due to their complex structure and weight, they are more prone to twisting around the pedicle, leading to ovarian torsion. This can result in reduced blood flow to the ovary and, if untreated, can cause necrosis of the ovarian tissue. Symptoms of ovarian torsion include acute pelvic pain, nausea, and vomiting, which require urgent surgical intervention. Explanation for the Incorrect Answers: B. Dysgerminoma Dysgerminomas are a type of germ cell tumor of the ovary. While they are the most common malignant ovarian tumor in young women, they are less likely to undergo torsion compared to benign cystic teratomas. Dysgerminomas are typically solid and not as prone to the torsion associated with large, cystic masses like dermoid cysts. They usually present as an abdominal mass with nonspecific symptoms rather than with acute pain due to torsion. C. Ovarian fibroma Ovarian fibromas are solid tumors composed of fibrous tissue. Although they can cause ovarian torsion, especially if they are large and pedunculated, they are less likely to undergo torsion than cystic tumors like benign cystic teratomas. Fibromas are often asymptomatic until they reach a significant size, and torsion is a relatively rare complication. When torsion does occur, it may present with abdominal pain, but it is less common compared to cystic ovarian masses. D. Brenner's tumor Brenner's tumors are rare, usually benign, ovarian tumors made up of transitional epithelial cells. They are typically small, solid, and less likely to cause torsion compared to cystic tumors. Brenner's tumors are often asymptomatic and discovered incidentally during surgery or imaging. Ovarian torsion is not a common complication of Brenner's tumors, as they lack the cystic, heavy components that contribute to torsion in other ovarian cyst types.

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman, gravida 1, para 1, presents to you because she wants to decrease her risk of ovarian cancer via a prophylactic oophorectomy. She has no chronic medical problems except obesity. Her gynecologic history is remarkable for ?rst sexual intercourse at age 15 years, four sexual partners in her entire life, and breastfeeding of her only child. Her Pap smear has shown exposure to HPV. She had infertility and conceived her only child with in vitro fertilization, and subsequently was taking birth control pills. She smokes one pack per week (for the last 10 years) and has an occasional drink with her husband. Her family history is remarkable for breast cancer in her mother and maternal grandmother and ovarian cancer in her maternal aunt. The most signi?cant risk factor for developing ovarian cancer is her:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Family history The most significant risk factor for developing ovarian cancer in this case is the family history of breast and ovarian cancer. Family history, particularly of ovarian cancer in a first-degree relative or multiple relatives (such as her maternal aunt), significantly increases the risk due to the potential inheritance of genetic mutations like BRCA1 and BRCA2, which are strongly associated with ovarian cancer. Explanation for incorrect options: B. HPV: While HPV (Human Papillomavirus) is a known risk factor for cervical cancer, it is not a significant risk factor for ovarian cancer. HPV is not linked to ovarian cancer in the way it is for cervical cancer. C. Low parity: Having fewer children (low parity) has been associated with a slightly increased risk of ovarian cancer. However, family history is a much stronger risk factor in this case. D. Birth control pills: The use of oral contraceptive pills actually reduces the risk of ovarian cancer over time. This protective effect is most notable with prolonged use (several years), making it less likely to be a risk factor in this case.

questions.text: A 55 year old lady presents with abdominal distension bleeding pelvic pain and respiratory distress.Clinical examination reveals feature of ascitis and CA-125 levels are elevated .The most likely diagnosis :
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) CA ovary The most likely diagnosis for this patient is ovarian cancer (CA ovary). The patient's symptomsâ€”abdominal distension, bleeding pelvic pain, respiratory distress, and ascitesâ€”are characteristic of advanced ovarian cancer. Elevated CA-125 levels further support this diagnosis, as CA-125 is a tumor marker that is often elevated in ovarian cancer, especially in cases of advanced disease with peritoneal spread (which can cause ascites and other symptoms). Ovarian cancer frequently presents with these non-specific symptoms, and ascites is a common feature in advanced stages. Explanation for incorrect options: B. CA cervix: Cervical cancer may present with symptoms like abnormal vaginal bleeding and pelvic pain, but it typically does not present with ascites or elevated CA-125 levels. Cervical cancer is more likely to be associated with symptoms like abnormal vaginal discharge, bleeding after intercourse, or postmenopausal bleeding, rather than the ascites seen in this case. C. CA lung: While lung cancer can present with respiratory distress, it is less likely to present with abdominal distension, pelvic pain, or ascites. CA-125 is not a common marker for lung cancer, and the clinical picture here is more consistent with ovarian cancer than lung cancer. D. Lymphoma: Lymphoma can cause abdominal distension and even respiratory distress if there is significant lymphadenopathy or organ involvement, but it typically does not cause elevated CA-125 levels. Lymphoma is also less likely to present with the characteristic combination of pelvic pain, ascites, and elevated CA-125 levels seen in this patient.

questions.text: 35 yrs old Lata, P2L2 with Rt sided ovarian mass c/o bleeding PV. Her FBS 72mg%. and S. inhibin levels raised. On histopathology, likely picture is :
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Call Exner bodies The most likely diagnosis for Lataâ€™s ovarian mass, based on her elevated serum inhibin levels, is a granulosa cell tumor of the ovary. Granulosa cell tumors often present with elevated inhibin levels, which is a key tumor marker for these types of tumors. On histopathology, the hallmark feature of granulosa cell tumors is the presence of Call Exner bodies. These are small, cystic spaces lined by granulosa cells, resembling glandular structures. These tumors often present with irregular vaginal bleeding due to their estrogen-secreting nature. Explanation for incorrect options: B. Crystalloids of Reinke: Crystalloids of Reinke are a characteristic feature of Sertoli-Leydig cell tumors, a type of sex-cord stromal tumor of the ovary. Sertoli-Leydig cell tumors may also present with elevated inhibin levels, but they are more likely to present with virilization due to testosterone secretion, which is not mentioned in this case. C. Psammoma bodies: Psammoma bodies are associated with serous tumors of the ovary, especially serous cystadenocarcinomas, which are malignant tumors. These bodies are concentric, calcified structures often seen on histopathological examination. They are not typically seen in granulosa cell tumors. D. Hobnail cells: Hobnail cells are characteristic of clear cell carcinoma of the ovary, a rare and aggressive form of ovarian cancer. Clear cell carcinomas may also present with elevated CA-125, but they do not feature elevated inhibin levels, and they typically do not have Call Exner bodies.

questions.text: A 72-year-old woman has been admitted with shortness of breath. On further questioning she says she has been unwell for about 8 weeks. She has decreased appetite and nausea when she eats. She has lost weight but her abdomen feels swollen. She appears pale and breathless on talking. Chest expansion is reduced on the right side, with dullness to percussion and decreased air entry at the right base. The abdomen is gen- erally distended with shifting dullness. There is a mass arising from the pelvis. Speculum examination is normal, but on bimanual palpation there is a fixed left iliac fossa mass of about 10 cm diameter. Her X ray and CT scan given below. What is the diagnosis
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Ovarian cancer The most likely diagnosis for this 72-year-old woman is ovarian cancer. The clinical presentation of abdominal distension, weight loss, decreased appetite, nausea, and a pelvic mass strongly suggests a malignancy. The physical examination findings of dullness to percussion, decreased air entry, and shifting dullness suggest the presence of ascites, which is commonly associated with advanced ovarian cancer. Ovarian cancer often presents with nonspecific symptoms like nausea, bloating, and abdominal swelling, and it is known to cause peritoneal metastasis, which can lead to the development of ascites and a palpable mass, as seen in this case. The fixed left iliac fossa mass of 10 cm in diameter on bimanual examination further supports the diagnosis of ovarian cancer. Explanation for incorrect options: A. Endometrial cancer: Endometrial cancer typically presents with abnormal vaginal bleeding, not the generalized symptoms of abdominal distension, weight loss, and ascites. The absence of abnormal uterine bleeding in this patient, along with the findings of a pelvic mass and ascites, makes endometrial cancer less likely. Additionally, endometrial cancer is less commonly associated with ascites than ovarian cancer. B. Colon cancer: Colon cancer can present with nonspecific symptoms like weight loss, nausea, and abdominal distension. However, colon cancer typically causes changes in bowel habits (like constipation or diarrhea) and may present with blood in the stool, none of which are mentioned in this case. The finding of a fixed pelvic mass and ascites is more characteristic of ovarian cancer than colon cancer, where masses are usually located more centrally in the abdomen. D. Breast cancer: While breast cancer can metastasize to the ovaries and cause secondary ovarian involvement, the primary presentation with abdominal distension, ascites, and a pelvic mass is more indicative of a primary ovarian malignancy. Breast cancer typically presents with a breast mass or abnormal mammogram findings and usually presents earlier with local or distant metastases, not as a primary cause of a pelvic mass with ascites.

choices.text: Use of combination oral contraceptive therapy

questions.text: A 30-year-woman presents to your office with the fear of developing ovarian cancer. Her 70-year-old grandmother recently died from ovarian cancer. You dis cuss with her the risks factors and prevention for ovarian cancer. Which of the following can decrease a womanâ€™s risk of ovarian cancer?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Use of combination oral contraceptive therapy The use of combination oral contraceptive therapy is a well-established method to reduce the risk of ovarian cancer. Oral contraceptives suppress ovulation, which in turn reduces the number of ovulatory cycles a woman experiences. This suppression of ovulation lowers the chance of the development of ovarian cancer, especially in women who have used them for extended periods (e.g., five years or more). The protective effect is thought to result from the decreased turnover of the ovarian epithelium, which reduces the potential for malignant transformation. Explanation for incorrect options: B. Menopause after age 55: While menopause itself is associated with a decrease in ovarian cancer risk due to the cessation of ovulatory cycles, menopause after age 55 does not necessarily reduce the risk of ovarian cancer. In fact, delayed menopause may increase the risk of ovarian cancer because it prolongs the number of ovulatory cycles over a woman's lifetime, thereby increasing the chances for ovarian carcinogenesis. C. Nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs): There is limited evidence suggesting that NSAIDs have a protective effect against ovarian cancer. Some studies have explored the potential role of NSAIDs in reducing inflammation and possibly reducing cancer risk, but there is no significant or consistent data linking NSAID use to a decreased risk of ovarian cancer. D. Nulliparity: Nulliparity, or having no children, is actually a risk factor for ovarian cancer, not a protective factor. Women who have never given birth have a higher risk of ovarian cancer compared to those who have had children, possibly due to the higher number of lifetime ovulatory cycles associated with nulliparity. E. Ovulation induction medications: Ovulation induction medications, such as clomiphene citrate, are used to help women conceive, but there is evidence that they may increase the risk of ovarian cancer. Long-term use of these medications, especially in women who do not conceive, may be associated with an elevated risk of ovarian tumors.

choices.text: Radical partial vulvectomy and bilateral inguinal lymphadenectomy

questions.text: A woman is found to have a unilateral invasive vulvar carcinoma that is 3 cm in diameter but not associated with evidence of lymph node spread. Initial management should consist of which of the following?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (E) Radical partial vulvectomy and bilateral inguinal lymphadenectomy The management of a unilateral invasive vulvar carcinoma that is 3 cm in diameter, with no evidence of lymph node spread, typically involves radical partial vulvectomy and bilateral inguinal lymphadenectomy. Vulvar carcinoma is generally treated by surgical resection, and the primary goal is to achieve clear surgical margins while also evaluating regional lymph nodes for metastasis. In this case, the tumor is 3 cm in diameter, which is considered a moderate size, and the lymph nodes should be assessed for metastasis with a bilateral inguinal lymphadenectomy. Even though there is no evidence of lymph node involvement initially, the inguinal nodes are frequently involved in vulvar carcinoma, and their removal helps with staging and further management. Explanation for incorrect options: A. Chemotherapy: Chemotherapy is not the primary treatment for early-stage vulvar carcinoma. It is typically reserved for advanced or metastatic disease. This patientâ€™s carcinoma is localized and, therefore, does not initially require chemotherapy. B. Radiation therapy: While radiation therapy may be used in certain cases of vulvar carcinoma, it is usually considered after surgery, either for adjuvant treatment or in cases of positive surgical margins or lymph node involvement. It is not the first-line treatment in the absence of those factors. C. Simple vulvectomy: A simple vulvectomy (removal of the tumor along with a margin of healthy tissue) is typically not sufficient for vulvar carcinoma when there is a risk of lymph node spread. In this case, a more comprehensive procedure such as radical partial vulvectomy is preferred to ensure proper removal of the tumor and assessment of the inguinal lymph nodes. D. Radical vulvectomy without inguinal lymphadenectomy: A radical vulvectomy involves the extensive removal of vulvar tissue, which is not necessary if there is no evidence of lymph node involvement. The inguinal lymph nodes are important for staging and treatment, so bilateral inguinal lymphadenectomy is indicated alongside the vulvectomy.

questions.text: A pa?ent is receiving external beam radia?on for treatment of meta-sta?c endometrial cancer. The treatment field includes the en?re pelvis. Which of the following tissues within this radiation field is the most radiosensitive?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Ovary The ovary is the most radiosensitive tissue among the options listed when exposed to external beam radiation within the pelvic region. The ovaries contain highly proliferative germ cells, which are particularly sensitive to radiation. In fact, radiation therapy can lead to ovarian failure, even with relatively low doses, especially in women of reproductive age. The ovaries have a high mitotic index, and radiation-induced damage to the DNA in rapidly dividing cells can result in ovarian atrophy, reduced fertility, or early menopause. Explanation for incorrect options: A. Vagina: The vagina is somewhat radiosensitive, but not as much as the ovaries. Radiation can cause vaginal fibrosis, atrophy, or stenosis, but these effects typically develop over a longer period of time, and the vagina is less sensitive compared to rapidly dividing tissues like the ovaries. C. Rectovaginal septum: The rectovaginal septum, like other connective tissues, can be affected by radiation, leading to fibrosis and tissue scarring. However, it is less radiosensitive than rapidly dividing tissues like the ovaries, which are more vulnerable to radiation-induced damage. D. Bladder: The bladder is relatively resistant to radiation compared to organs like the ovaries. While radiation can cause bladder inflammation, fibrosis, or cystitis, it is not as sensitive to radiation as reproductive tissues. E. Rectum: The rectum, like the bladder, is also somewhat resistant to radiation but can be affected by radiation-induced damage, leading to symptoms like rectal bleeding or proctitis. However, the rectum is not as radiosensitive as the ovaries, which are more prone to radiation-induced cell death and dysfunction.

choices.text: Return to the office in 1 to 2 months to recheck the ovaries
Schedule a CT s can of the pelvis
Admit to the hospital for exploratory laparotomy

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman presents to you for routine well-woman examination. She has had two normal vaginal deliveries and is healthy. She smokes one pack of cigare?es per day. She has no gynecologic complaints. Her last menstrual period was 3 weeks ago. During the pelvic examination, you notice that her left ovary is enlarged to 5 cm in diameter. Which of the following is the best recommendation to this patient?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Return to the office in 1 to 2 months to recheck the ovaries In a healthy, asymptomatic 25-year-old woman with a 5 cm ovarian cyst that was discovered incidentally during a routine pelvic exam, the most appropriate recommendation is to recheck the ovaries in 1 to 2 months. Many functional cysts (such as follicular or corpus luteal cysts) are common in women of reproductive age and tend to resolve spontaneously over time. A period of observation is usually sufficient unless the patient develops symptoms or the cyst shows concerning features (such as rapid growth, solid components, or other characteristics that suggest malignancy). Explanation for incorrect options: A. Order CA-125 testing: CA-125 is a tumor marker that is often elevated in ovarian cancer, but it is not specific and can be elevated in many other conditions, including benign ovarian cysts, endometriosis, and pelvic infections. It is not a first-line test for a simple, asymptomatic ovarian cyst in a young woman. Testing should generally be reserved for cases with higher suspicion of ovarian cancer, such as in older women or those with concerning clinical features. B. Schedule outpatient diagnostic laparoscopy: Laparoscopy is an invasive procedure and is typically reserved for cases where the cyst is symptomatic, suspected to be malignant, or does not resolve with observation. Since the patient is asymptomatic and the cyst is small, laparoscopy is not indicated at this time. D. Schedule a CT scan of the pelvis: A CT scan is not necessary for the initial evaluation of a simple ovarian cyst in a young woman. Ultrasound is typically the imaging modality of choice to evaluate ovarian cysts, and a CT scan is more useful for detecting metastatic disease or for further evaluation of complex cysts. E. Admit to the hospital for exploratory laparotomy: An exploratory laparotomy is an invasive procedure and would be unnecessary for a benign ovarian cyst. Most ovarian cysts in young women are benign and resolve without surgical intervention. A laparotomy is typically reserved for cases of suspected ovarian cancer, torsion, or other severe complications.

choices.text: Excision of the omental metastasis and ovarian cystectomy
Excision of the omental metastasis and unilateral oophorectomy
Omentectomy, total abdominal hysterectomy, and bilateral salpingo-oophorectomy

questions.text: A 54-year-old woman undergoes a laparotomy because of a pelvic mass. At exploratory laparotomy, a unilateral ovarian neoplasm is dis covered that is accompanied by a large omental metastasis. Frozen sec?on diagnosis confirms metasta?c serous cystadenocarcinoma. Which of the following is the most appropriate intraoperative course of action?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (E) Omentectomy, total abdominal hysterectomy, and bilateral salpingo-oophorectomy In the case of metastatic serous cystadenocarcinoma, the most appropriate course of action involves complete surgical staging. This includes omental resection (omentectomy), bilateral salpingo-oophorectomy (removal of both ovaries), and total abdominal hysterectomy (removal of the uterus). This comprehensive approach is recommended for ovarian cancer, as it aims to remove all visible tumor tissue and reduce the risk of recurrence. It also addresses potential metastases to the uterus and other reproductive organs, which are common in ovarian cancer. Omentectomy is essential because the omentum is a frequent site of ovarian cancer metastasis, and removal helps prevent further spread of the disease. Total abdominal hysterectomy is generally performed to remove the uterus, as ovarian cancer can also spread to the uterus. Bilateral salpingo-oophorectomy is performed to remove both ovaries, which is standard practice in ovarian cancer management, even when the disease appears unilateral, to reduce the risk of recurrence and better control the spread of the disease. Explanation for incorrect options: A. Excision of the omental metastasis and ovarian cystectomy: This is not appropriate in cases of ovarian cancer with metastasis. A simple ovarian cystectomy would be insufficient, as it does not address the potential spread to other organs, such as the omentum or uterus. Additionally, leaving behind metastatic disease would likely result in a poor prognosis. B. Omentectomy and ovarian cystectomy: While omentectomy is necessary to remove metastatic tissue from the omentum, ovarian cystectomy is not adequate in this case of serous cystadenocarcinoma. A more extensive procedure, such as a bilateral salpingo-oophorectomy, is required to adequately treat ovarian cancer. C. Excision of the omental metastasis and unilateral oophorectomy: While removing the omental metastasis is essential, a unilateral oophorectomy is insufficient for treating ovarian cancer, particularly when there is a risk of bilateral involvement or widespread metastasis. Bilateral oophorectomy is preferred to ensure thorough management of the disease. D. Omentectomy and bilateral salpingo-oophorectomy: Although omentectomy and bilateral salpingo-oophorectomy are important parts of the surgical approach, this option omits total abdominal hysterectomy. The uterus should also be removed, as it may harbor microscopic cancer or be at risk for metastasis, and the total hysterectomy provides better surgical staging and comprehensive treatment.

questions.text: A 21-year-old woman presents with left lower quadrant pain. An anterior 7-cm ?rm adnexal mass is palpated. Ultrasound image is shown below . What percentage of these tumors are bilateral?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) 10%. A 21-year-old woman with left lower quadrant pain and an adnexal mass likely has an ovarian tumor, such as a mature cystic teratoma (dermoid cyst), which is a common benign ovarian tumor in this age group. The likelihood of such tumors being bilateral is around 10%. Mature cystic teratomas are one of the types of ovarian tumors that can present bilaterally in approximately 10% of cases. In addition to teratomas, endometriomas (often seen in young women with a history of endometriosis) may also have a higher incidence of being bilateral. Given that the patient is 21 years old and the tumor size is 7 cm, a benign ovarian tumor like a teratoma or an endometrioma is a possible diagnosis. Explanation of incorrect responses: A. Less than 1%: This is too low. While most ovarian cysts are unilateral, benign tumors like teratomas have a bilateral occurrence rate of around 10%, which is higher than less than 1%. B. 2% to 3%: This is still lower than the actual rate. Although some benign ovarian tumors can present bilaterally, the percentage is generally higher than 2-3% in the case of teratomas and endometriomas. D. 50%: This is much too high. While some specific ovarian tumors may present bilaterally, a 50% bilateral occurrence rate would be unusually high. The 10% rate is considered the typical percentage for bilateral ovarian tumors like teratomas.

questions.text: A 6-year-old girl is noted to have breast development and vaginal spotting. No abnormal hair growth is noted. A 10-cm ovarian mass is palpated on rectal examination. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Granulosa-theca cell tumor. A granulosa-theca cell tumor is the most likely diagnosis for this 6-year-old girl, given her breast development (thelarche), vaginal spotting, and the presence of a large ovarian mass (10 cm). Granulosa cell tumors are sex cord-stromal tumors that secrete estrogen, leading to premature pubertal signs such as breast development and vaginal bleeding. These tumors often present with abnormal bleeding and sometimes a palpable ovarian mass in young girls. Granulosa-theca cell tumors are the most common estrogen-secreting tumors in prepubertal girls and can result in signs of precocious puberty. Explanation of incorrect responses: A. Benign cystic tumor (dermoid): Dermoid cysts (mature cystic teratomas) are common ovarian tumors in children, but they do not typically cause hormonal effects like breast development or vaginal bleeding. These tumors are usually asymptomatic unless they cause complications such as torsion. Dermoid cysts are generally not associated with the precocious puberty seen in this case. B. Sertoliâ€“Leydig cell tumor: Sertoli-Leydig cell tumors (also known as androblastomas) are androgen-secreting tumors that can lead to virilization, including abnormal hair growth (hirsutism), deepening of the voice, and clitoromegaly. However, the absence of abnormal hair growth in this case makes this diagnosis less likely. C. Congenital adrenal hyperplasia (CAH): CAH is a condition that causes adrenal hyperplasia, leading to excessive androgen production. This can result in virilization symptoms such as hirsutism and enlarged clitoris. However, in this case, the absence of virilization and the presence of an estrogen-secreting ovarian mass make CAH less likely. CAH does not typically present with estrogen-driven puberty and vaginal bleeding.

choices.text: Papillary vegetations within a cystic ovary
An ovarian cyst with a diameter of 4 cm
Demonstration of arterial and venous flow by Doppler imaging

questions.text: A 54-year-old woman presents for well-woman examination. On pelvic examination you palpate an enlarged, tender right adnexal mass. You order a pelvic ultrasound as the next step in this patientâ€™s evaluation. Which of the following sonographic characteristics of the cyst in this patient would warrant further evaluation for possible ovarian malignancy?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Papillary vegetations within a cystic ovary. Papillary vegetations within a cystic ovary are highly suggestive of an ovarian malignancy. These papillary projections, which appear as solid nodules or masses protruding into the cystic space, are often seen in serous cystadenocarcinomas, endometrioid ovarian cancers, or other malignant tumors of the ovary. The presence of such structures is an important sonographic feature that warrants further evaluation, typically with more advanced imaging modalities (such as CT or MRI), and may lead to biopsy or surgical removal for confirmation. Explanation of incorrect responses: A. Lack of pelvic ascites: The absence of pelvic ascites does not suggest malignancy in and of itself. Ascites may occur in later stages of ovarian cancer, but its absence does not rule out the presence of ovarian cancer. Thus, the lack of ascites is not an indicator for further evaluation for malignancy. C. An ovarian cyst with a diameter of 4 cm: Simple ovarian cysts of 4 cm in diameter are generally benign, especially if the cyst is unilocular (one chamber) and has a smooth border. Most functional cysts of this size resolve spontaneously and do not require immediate concern for malignancy. Although larger cysts (e.g., over 5 cm) are sometimes more concerning, a simple cyst of 4 cm is typically low-risk for malignancy. D. Demonstration of arterial and venous flow by Doppler imaging: The presence of blood flow seen on Doppler ultrasound does not alone indicate malignancy. Both benign and malignant ovarian tumors can show vascularity on Doppler imaging. It is the characteristics of the cyst (such as solid components, irregular borders, or papillary projections) that are more relevant for distinguishing benign from malignant tumors. Doppler flow is not a distinguishing factor by itself for ovarian cancer.

questions.text: A 26-year-old G2P1 presents to the gynecologist complaining of increasing hair growth on her face, chest, and abdomen, but the hair on her head is receding in the temporal regions. She also has had problems with acne. On physical examination the patient has signi?cant amounts of coarse, dark hair on her face, chest, and abdomen. On pelvic examination she has an enlarged clitoris. She has a 7-cm left adnexal mass. Select the ovarian tumor from below that is most likely to be associated with the clinical picture.
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Sertoli-Leydig cell tumor. Sertoli-Leydig cell tumors, also known as androblastomas, are a type of ovarian sex cord-stromal tumor that can produce androgens (male hormones). This patient's symptoms of increased facial and body hair, receding hairline (temporal baldness), and acne are all signs of hyperandrogenism, which is commonly seen in Sertoli-Leydig cell tumors. Additionally, the presence of an enlarged clitoris is another indication of androgen excess, as virilization can occur with these tumors. The 7-cm left adnexal mass further supports the possibility of an ovarian tumor, particularly one that could be secreting androgens. These tumors are more common in young women, and the clinical presentation aligns with this diagnosis. Explanation of incorrect responses: A. Granulosa tumor: Granulosa cell tumors are estrogen-producing tumors that typically present with symptoms related to estrogen excess, such as precocious puberty, menstrual irregularities, or endometrial hyperplasia. They do not generally produce significant androgen excess, and thus would be less likely to cause the hyperandrogenic symptoms seen in this patient (e.g., increased hair growth, acne, virilization). C. Gonadoblastoma: Gonadoblastomas are rare tumors that are typically seen in patients with gonadal dysgenesis or disorders of sexual development, such as Turner syndrome or 46,XY gonadal dysgenesis. While they can cause ovarian or testicular masses, they are not typically associated with the significant hyperandrogenism and virilization seen in this patient. D. Krukenberg tumor: Krukenberg tumors are metastatic tumors that usually originate from gastrointestinal malignancies, such as gastric cancer, and spread to the ovaries.
