These tumors are typically bilateral and present with abdominal distension or ascites rather than signs of hyperandrogenism. Therefore, they are unlikely to be the cause of this patient's symptoms.

questions.text: A 56-year-old postmenopausal woman presents complaining of vaginal bleeding. Her uterus is slightly enlarged and she has a 6-cm right adnexal mass. Endometrial biopsy shows adenocarcinoma of the endometrium. Select the ovarian tumor from below that is most likely to be associated with the clinical picture.
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Granulosa tumor. Granulosa cell tumors are a type of sex cord-stromal tumor of the ovary, which are known to produce estrogens. This can lead to symptoms of endometrial hyperplasia or adenocarcinoma of the endometrium, as seen in this patient. The estrogen production by granulosa tumors may result in vaginal bleeding, a common symptom in postmenopausal women with these tumors. The associated adnexal mass is a characteristic feature of ovarian tumors. Granulosa tumors are often slow-growing, and while they are estrogen-producing, they can lead to endometrial carcinoma due to the long-term stimulation of the endometrial lining by estrogen. Explanation of incorrect responses: B. Sertoli-Leydig cell tumor: Sertoli-Leydig cell tumors are androgen-producing tumors, and they are associated with hyperandrogenism rather than estrogen excess. Symptoms like virilization (e.g., deepening of the voice, hirsutism) are more common with these tumors, which is not consistent with this patient's presentation of vaginal bleeding and endometrial adenocarcinoma. C. Immature teratoma: Immature teratomas are a type of germ cell tumor, typically seen in younger women, and can cause abdominal pain or mass effect. They are not associated with estrogen production or endometrial carcinoma. The presentation of vaginal bleeding and adenocarcinoma of the endometrium is not typical of immature teratomas. D. Krukenberg tumor: Krukenberg tumors are metastatic tumors, typically originating from gastric adenocarcinoma or other gastrointestinal cancers. They usually present as bilateral ovarian masses and are not associated with estrogen production or endometrial carcinoma. The patient's unilateral adnexal mass and the primary endometrial carcinoma make Krukenberg tumor an unlikely cause.

questions.text: This adnexal finding which is frequently seen with complete molar pregnancy is best managed by which of the following
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Suction evacuation. Complete molar pregnancy is a condition where an abnormal fertilization occurs, leading to the formation of trophoblastic tissue instead of a normal fetus. One of the common features seen in complete molar pregnancy is the presence of theca lutein cysts in the ovaries, which are large, benign cysts resulting from elevated levels of human chorionic gonadotropin (hCG). The management of a complete molar pregnancy involves the suction evacuation of the molar tissue from the uterus. This procedure is crucial not only for removing the abnormal pregnancy but also to prevent complications like hemorrhage, infection, or the development of malignant gestational trophoblastic disease (e.g., choriocarcinoma). Once the molar tissue is evacuated, theca lutein cysts typically resolve on their own or with the normalization of hCG levels. Explanation of incorrect responses: A. Oophorectomy: This involves the removal of the ovary and is typically reserved for situations where there is malignancy or severe ovarian pathology. In the case of a molar pregnancy with theca lutein cysts, oophorectomy is unnecessary as the cysts are usually benign and resolve after the molar pregnancy is treated. Removal of the ovary is not warranted unless there are complications like torsion or malignancy. B. Oophoropexy: This is a surgical procedure used to secure an ovary in cases of ovarian torsion or when the ovary is at risk of torsion. However, in the case of theca lutein cysts associated with molar pregnancies, oophoropexy is not indicated. The cysts are typically self-limiting and will resolve once the molar tissue is evacuated. C. Ovarian cystectomy: This involves the surgical removal of an ovarian cyst. While cystectomy might be used for other types of ovarian cysts, theca lutein cysts related to molar pregnancy are usually benign and do not require removal unless there is a complication like torsion or rupture, which is uncommon. The cysts typically regress after the molar pregnancy is treated.

questions.text: Wallthard cell nest is seen in which of the following ovarian tumours
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Brenner's tumor. Brenner's tumor is a rare type of ovarian tumor that is often benign and composed of transitional cells resembling the urothelium. A distinctive histopathological feature of Brenner's tumor is the presence of Wallthard cell nests, which are clusters of transitional cells found within the tumor. These cell nests are a characteristic feature of Brenner's tumor and are useful in differentiating it from other types of ovarian tumors. Explanation of incorrect responses: B. Dermoid cyst: Dermoid cysts, also known as mature cystic teratomas, are the most common type of ovarian germ cell tumor. These cysts are made up of various tissues, including hair, skin, and sometimes teeth or bone. Dermoid cysts do not contain Wallthard cell nests. Instead, they are characterized by their ability to differentiate into a variety of tissue types, but not transitional epithelium as seen in Brenner's tumor. C. Krukenberg's tumor: Krukenberg tumors are metastatic ovarian tumors, usually originating from gastrointestinal malignancies, most commonly gastric cancer. These tumors typically contain mucin-producing signet-ring cells. Wallthard cell nests are not found in Krukenberg tumors, as they are characterized by a different type of cellular arrangement and tissue origin. D. Endodermal sinus tumor: Also known as yolk sac tumor, this is another type of germ cell tumor. It is characterized by the presence of Schiller-Duval bodies, which are structures resembling glomeruli. Wallthard cell nests are not a feature of endodermal sinus tumors, which instead have a different histological appearance, notably the presence of these characteristic bodies.
